Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: How to arrow push and study way too much material at once.
A lot about biochemistry.
I gained a solid understanding of fundamental concepts in biochemistry such as metabolism.
Understanding of biosynthesis reactions, the role of enzymes, cofactors, and ribozymes.

How to study a LOT of material for the third and fourth exams on (third) glycolysis/citric acid cycle/oxidative phosphorylation/fatty acid synthesis and degradation, and (fourth) membrane lipid and steroid biosynthesis/one-carbon metabolism/nucleotide biosynthesis/amino acid biosynthesis (all 20 of the amino acids). The first exam was probably a third of the material seen on the third and fourth exams, and the second exam was about half. Professor Breaker is a great, animated teacher, but his pacing often fell behind, so we ended up rushing a lot of things for the last exam (namely, biosynthesis of all 20 of the amino acids). Professor Engelman was less engaging -- his lectures were a little more monotone, so harder to pay attention to. The information was well-encompassed in his slides, though. The grading for exams was really harsh for the most part (although the TA's were strangely nice for the second exam) -- there are times when we got points off for not including in our answers information that wasn't even asked for in the question.
RNA world, Riboswitches, Amino acids, Nucleotides; all burned into my memory!

This class was a strong introduction to biochemical concepts and pathways that made me feel as though I have a decent core understanding of the subject. It gives enough detail for material to make sense without overburdening students, making the concepts relatively clear and digestible.

A basic understanding of biochem, how to integrate bio and orgo, some understanding of important metabolic pathways. How to memorize a ton of information in a short period of time. I might have memorized these pathways in detail right before the exams, but now it just feels like I have an approximate knowledge of many things. The instructor wasn't great at explaining the big picture. Instead, we spent a lot of time painstakingly learning very specific pathways, and he seemed to expect us to understand how these related to the big picture implicitly and magically understand what was important to know for the tests. This did not happen for me.
I learned a lot about biochemistry concepts, as well as ways to apply organic chemistry knowledge to biological systems.
I learned a lot of fundamental concepts of biochemistry and went into great depth in topics that I was familiar with from previous courses but did not yet have a full understanding of.
I learned about the biochemistry: from the citric acid cycle to Ribozymes.
Wide -reaching knowledge of biochemical processes but also knowledge of specific important mechanisms.
Excellent class! It was really amazing to apply organic chemistry in what felt like a tangible, biological context. The class focuses heavily on synthesis pathways, RNA, enzymes, and cofactors.
I gained some understanding of the biochemical mechanisms that occur in living organisms.

A pretty good general overview of the principles by which metabolism works in the body. Some knowledge about specific pathways, but overall a good fundamental understanding of the building blocks and common principles of biochemistry.
I learned concepts in metabolism, membranes, and macromolecules and was exposed to interpretation of experimental data.

Basics of biochemistry as a medical school prep-type class/requirement. Wide range of topics covered, some of it quite mechanism heavy with less emphasis on medical relevance, but still great way to apply learning from orgo and bio to the body systems
I learned all about Biochem and how your body works!

This class taught me a lot about the in-depth mechanics of many of the things I learned in Bio 101, which I appreciated. I learned a lot about metabolic pathways and how to memorize what was going to be on the test, but I'm not sure if I developed any meaningful critical thinking skills for biochemistry itself as a subject.
I learned about biochemistry.
It was cool to learn biochem stuff from the guy who created some of these theories
It was interesting to see how orgo related back to biological processes.
Protein synthesis, amino acid metabolism, glycolysis...the whole works!
Not much. The course was almost entirely memorization.

This course had breadth and depth when it came to going more in-depth than the introductory biochemistry course (BIOL 101), which is good for pre-med students but for people who want to learn biochemistry. There was more breadth than depth in my opinion, since we covered a lot in one semester, but depth was a goal, but it wasn't quite there. But that's okay. There were certain parts of the curriculum that had more factual-based learning and then some parts that required knowledge of mechanisms, so there was variety there, which is okay.
Biochemistry
I learned about DNA, RNA, protein synthesis, glycolysis, citric acid cycle, lipid synthesis/degradation, amino acid synthesis, purine/pyrimidine synthesis, and riboswitches.
This class gave me a deeper insight to biochemistry and helped me discover roots of biological processes in all organisms
I learned a lot about protein structure, membrane biochemistry, DNA replication, metabolism, one-carbon metabolism, nucleic acid synthesis, and amino acid synthesis.

I learned about the structures of amino acids, carbohydrates, lipids, and nucleic acids (purines and pyrimidine components especially); enzyme kinetics; glycolysis, the citric acid cycle, the electron transport chain; fatty acid metabolism; single-carbon donation pathways; amino acid synthesis; purine and pyrimidine synthesis; etc. One of my favorite moments was learning about oxygen binding cooperativity in hemoglobin and how hemoglobin is biochemically tuned to bind oxygen at high pressures in the lungs and release it later on at lower pressures in the tissues that need it.
I learned the amino acids and some basic cycles in biological systems that provide energy to the system.
I learned the basics of biochemistry and how they build from organic chemistry.
Strength: interesting material. Weakness: too much material.
Very hard, very complex. Very interesting.
The course is very well taught but we weren't able to cover all of the content that was initially outlined on the syllabus. The pacing should be re-evaluated.

- very engaging, passionate professor 
- I liked going over mechanisms and the topics chosen by the professor 
- organization of slides would be helpful; sometimes the slides felt scattered with material that was related was not together in the powerpoint
The strengths are Professor Breakers ability to convey complicated concepts to us in a manner that was fun yet challenging.

Breaker is a great professor and an organized lecturer, and he surely cares about his students. Unfortunately, an overview of biochemistry in one semester was always going to feel rushed. But if I had to do it again, I would want to be taught by Breaker.

Strength: Professor Breaker is really excited about the material, so his teaching is engaging. He's also good at explaining things and answering questions. 

Weakness: The TA's were rather harsh in some of their grading on exam questions -- sometimes we got points off for not including in our answers information that wasn't even asked for in the question. The material gets exponentially harder over the course of the four exams, so be prepared for studying to only get tougher. The third and fourth exams included an outrageous amount of material. It wasn't clear if we should memorize every mechanism of glycolysis/citric acid cycle/oxidative phosphorylation/fatty acid synthesis and degradation, and Professor Breaker just told us to use our best judgment about what was most important. I thought fatty acid synthesis and degradation probably wasn't as important as the first three concepts, but low and behold, the only mechanism we had to draw full-out was fatty acid degradation. Basically, memorize everything.

Great content, very relevant and loved the medical points. Enjoyed having no cumulative final. However, exams were not evenly spaced out, leading to some exams covering 12 lectures (Exam 3 right before Thanksgiving break), and then one covering 6 lectures (Exam 4 only 2 weeks after Exam 3). Still loved this class!

Strengths: no problem sets, dedicated teaching staff (professors and TFs alike), interesting material, more survey style than MB&B, so you get to cover the most interesting parts of each topic

Weaknesses: Large volume of material that is difficult for the professors to get through in the amount of time allotted.

The structure is good--four noncumulative exams. However, there was a lot of nitty-gritty information on each test and it felt random as to what was considered important and what wasn't. It would have been nice to have some practice non-graded psets in between the tests so we would have some idea of what we were expected to know for the tests.
This course was VERY hard. It's hard to keep up when sometimes the professor takes a lot of time for some lectures but others he flies by in less than one class period.

Professor Breaker was a good lecturer, and there were always multiple review sessions, which were very helpful and appreciated. I would have liked practice exams for each section of the course, as I often felt unprepared for the types of questions or the level of specificity asked on the exams.

Strengths: I really enjoyed this course! The way that the course was set up (4 noncumulative tests) allowed us to focus and get a more in-depth understanding of biology. Breaker and Engelman were great lecturers and I felt like I learned a lot in this course. I think the review sessions offered by Breaker before the exams were really helpful in focusing our studies on important concepts. 

Weaknesses: The latter half of the course felt a bit rushed, but Breaker mentioned that it was his first time covering the material.

Very difficult to gauge what material we should study for the exam. I always found myself studying well but for the wrong things. Would have appreciated a little more clarity - I think if he is going to cover so much material so extensively he should make it more clear what topics and to what depth we are expected to recall.
Strengths are the four exams and no finals. Weakness was that it felt a bit rushed at the end so maybe better planning of material throughout the semester.

Professor Breaker is an amazing and funny professor whose curiosity is infectious. The key concepts basis, rather than details basis, to the course makes biochemistry intuitive and interesting. Great TA team.
Some exams seemed to have an excessive amount of material covered, especially the two later exams. I think I might have benefited from a more focused material range for this part of the course.

It could be made a little more clear what level of detail we were expected to know on the exams, as the lectures focused on going through mechanisms which would be impossible to memorize in their entirety. Although it seemed a little daunting at first, I actually liked how there were just 4 exams, each 25% for the class. This meant that there was not a cumulative, which makes a lot of sense to me in terms of relative importance of pure memorization versus conceptual understanding.
no practice tests
Great lectures, great professor, great structure - no weakness

I thought this course was organized very well. The lectures were easy to follow as long as you paid attention and the professor worked hard to answer questions. The exam breakdown was ideal with four non-cumulative exams. I thought this allowed me to really learn the material without being too overwhelmed.

I would have appreciated a more organized class and lectures that were more than Professor Breaker just narrating reactions that were already on the slides (and most reactions that we didn't even have to memorize for the exams). Though Breaker is a good lecturer at times, the material he teaches can be confusing and often too detailed for our knowledge.
Professor Breaker was great, but the course was too slow in the beginning and fast at the end.

bby Breaker is a wholesome icon and this class surprisingly retained my interest (more so than previous gen chem and orgo classes)

while I understand this was his first time teaching the whole biochem semester, the four midterm thing was great because nothing was cumulative but also I have no clue how it impacted our final grades (we're about to find out though)

The course was strong in that there was definitely a level of consistency throughout the semester. After the first exam, we knew how to study and how to develop our skills for the next exam. However, I did feel like the professor was a bit of an air head. He didn't care about how well we knew the material, or whether or not our section times actually worked for us.
Lots of memorization, no rubric for exams which can get tricky, great prof.
Strengths of the course were the incredibly dedicated TAs and the occasional medical relevance pointed out.

Strengths: good breadth of topics, Dr. Breaker is a pretty good lecturer, receptive to questions and holds review sessions (but more like Q&A type of things), he is patient in explaining topics, clear and concise lecturing, TAs (Javi) held review sessions which were really great and they were patient and helped as much as they could (considering that sometimes Dr. Breaker didn't even make the test until several days before) 

Weaknesses: the third midterm was NOT fun since there was no clear guidance on what to study, how to study, what the test formate was like; test format was a bit ambiguous for this and the final exam but there were practice exams for the first 2 exams which was very nice - honestly, the third midterm was very unfair in my opinion- need more guidance for this; a lot of topics, and maybe should have been more organized - sometimes we ran over time and that was not okay for a lecture class

I thought Breaker was a really good professor, and his tests were very fair. There was an emphasis on understanding the material as opposed to simply memorizing it, which is necessary in biology classes. The material was taught well but the textbook isn't great. I also wish the course itself could go a little more in depth into some of the topics, but I guess that is what the MBB biochem is known for.
Great course and lots to learn. Nothing too crazy or complicated

Strengths: I love how there is no cumulative final-- there are four midterm exams, so you don't have a final exam for this class during finals period, unless you miss an exam then you have to take a cumulative final during finals period. Prof Breaker is also a nice professor.
Weaknesses: we didn't really learn much about regulation during metabolism, which I feel like is supposed to be an important part of biochem
The course was very well facilitated for student learning

A big strength of this course is Prof. Breaker. He is really organized, a wonderful and engaging professor, and very willing to help students with material they find confusing. Another strength is that the course covers material in depth, while also giving a nice overview of various topics in biochemistry. One weakness was that the expectations for exams were a little unclear in terms of what we needed to studyfor example, it was mentioned several times that we wouldn't be tested on mechanisms but we have several mechanisms questions on exams.

The strength of this course it that the subject matter is manageable and fascinating in the first half of the semester. Its weakness is that, however fascinating, it is not manageable during the second half of the semester. The difficulty of the class increases dramatically upon the introduction of glycolysis and the rest of cellular respiration. The class is not difficult because the material is difficult, but because the material is overwhelming in quantity. Moreover, unclear expectations about what material would be tested increased the difficulty of the class. Both the overwhelming quantity of material and unclear expectations on the part of the professor should be resolved for the next iteration of this class.

It doesn't have a final and there's no homework. Still, we sometimes got practice exams, but never received answer keys. We can't learn what we are doing wrong if we don't get answers. The class also requires so much attention to detail that you memorize everything for a second and then forget it all after.

Strengths:
- good overview of topics in biochemistry

Weaknesses:
- towards the end, the topics started feeling a little random
I thought the glycolysis/TCA cycle/electron transport chain lectures were pretty disorganized and hard to follow.

You gotta take this class if you're taking it so my recommendation doesn't really matter. I've heard some people say MB&B300 is better and to be honest it's most likely just picking your poison. I thought that breaker was a great teacher - that being said, he exams were unfair and the organization of the class was poor. Not bad, not great, have fun.
Yes, if they have motivation to do the work necessary to learn.
I would recommend this course to students who seek a more basic understanding of biochemistry.
Yes. The material is fascinating!
Only take if you absolutely need the class.

I don't think one semester is enough for even a broad picture of biochemistry, and this course often feels rushed because of the sheer scope of the material. But if you must take it, at least you have Prof Breaker

I'd take this MCDB biochem over the MB&B biochem if you 1) want to avoid a final exam, 2) want a better chance at a good grade at the end (the MB&B class is notoriously filled with high achievers, and although the MCDB version is full of premeds, I think the average is probably lower in this class), and 3) are okay with learning a bunch of extra information, most of which probably won't be as useful on the MCAT as you think it will be.
Yes! Debated whether to take MCDB or MBB, so grateful I took this one instead. I genuinely enjoyed the course material, and appreciated the fact that emphasis was on learning versus grades.

If you're deciding between MCDB and MB&B, take this one. Professor Breaker is fantastic, the expectations are reasonable, and the 9:25 meeting time is definitely surmountable. You will get all the information you need from the course, so don't worry about that, either.
No, but if you're taking this you probably have to. Make sure to interact with the TAs, especially before the tests.
I would recommend this course to any student who needs to have a biochemistry course. I felt that it was well-taught and well-organized, and I enjoyed it.

I took this class because I wanted to, not as a requirement, but I honestly don't know if I would recommend anyone else to do the same. I heard the MB&B class was a lot better, so I would encourage you to try that version instead if you want a better biochemistry experience. We had no problem sets or practice exams, and had no idea what would be on any exam or any way to practice. The lectures were not enjoyable.
I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The 4 noncumulative exam is great. Breaker and Engelman are also amazing lecturers!
Absolutely

I would not recommend this course to another student. If it's a prerequisite for something you want to do later on, bite the bullet, study hard, and get through. But if not, Yale offers many other courses that you'd find more enjoyable and get much more out of.

Yeah. I think the material is very interesting and I enjoyed learning the material. I think its very difficult to do well on exams even with tons of studying. Still not sure what I could have done to do better on exams - possibly studying with someone else or meeting frequently with a TA for help with difficult concepts.

I would definitely recommend this course over the mbb biochemistry. Four non cumulative exams and no final is huge, especially for a class like biochemistry where there is so much material covered. Breaker is a great professor who really tries hard during his lectures to make sure you understand the materials, and is overall a pretty good lecturer.

Yes; if you enjoy understanding science intuitively (ie: learn a logical concept and make speculations on specific mechanisms from there), then you'll enjoy it. If you really enjoy the nitty gritty of biochem, this class is not as into that.
Yes, this course gave a strong background in concepts in biochemistry.

Yes, I really liked this version of biochem and how it was structured with the four exams. Dr. Breaker was very invested and excited about the class which made the lectures engaging. I didn't get as much of this sense from Dr. Engelman, but he only lectured for 4 classes.
Totally! Everyone should know how the body works
I would definitely recommend this course to another student in need of a biochem class. The non cumulative exams really helped with studying and the professor was great.

I think I would recommend this class over the MB&B biochem even though it is MWF 9:25 guys just look past that for a hot sec. I feel that on the whole, my friends in the MB&B class really didn't enjoy their experience, while the only time I didn't enjoy MCDB biochem was when we had Engelman for like two weeks

You probably have no choice. Become good friends with your TA, and try to go to Javi's sections instead of the other TAs' sections. They try their best but they literally don't know anything, whereas Javi actually has a solid grasp on the material. Definitely go to Javi's review sessions. Don't get caught up on the small stuff on the slides, they're there to waste your time while you inevitably cram for assessments that test your understanding of material taught 2 days earlier.
You have to for premed
Yes! This was the first premed requirement that I've taken in 3 years at Yale that have given me a true, fundamental understanding of chemical processes
Only if you have to take it.

Yes, Dr. Breaker is a good lecturer and it's not as intense in the details as MB&B biochemistry is, but that is okay! It was his first time teaching it and reorganizing the material in his own way so hopefully it will be better in the years to come. It's just a lot of stuff that should probably be more concisely organized, but again, hopefully that improves.

Prof. Breaker was great, but even his engaging lectures couldn't save this class for me. The amount of dense information required for the exams made this class seem like a third semester of orgo. There are much easier core MCDB classes. Don't take unless you have to, and prepare for a lot of work.
Yes, great biochemistry course.
I'd recommend this class because I felt like the exams were fair in the sense that if you memorized and understood every word in the slides, you'd end up with at worst an A-.
I would recommend this course to another student because it is extremely interesting, even though it is difficult

I would definitely recommend this course, especially over the MB&B biochemistry (@ any pre-med making this decision). Biochemistry will require a lot of attention and time regardless of which course you take, but I genuinely liked Prof. Breaker's teaching style and the topics we covered in this class. I cannot stress enough the importance of the professor who is teaching you materialI have taken a lot of lecture-style classes, and Prof. Breaker is probably the best lecturer I've had. He's clear, knows how to pace himself so students follow what he's saying, and organizes review sessions before exams to cover any gaps in our understanding. The material can be tough, but Prof. Breaker guides you through it, and if there's anything confusing he and TA's are happy to answer questions. I would also note that I believe this was the first year that Prof. Breaker was completely in charge of the course (with Engelman covering just 4 lectures), which is maybe why I liked it so much.

Yes! If you want to know more about how chemistry explains biology, take this class! I think this was Professor Breaker's first (or one of his first) time teaching the course, and it was still a good class. One thing to note is that mechanisms were a focus of the exams despite Breaker's instructions "not to study the mechanisms." Breaker loves mechanisms and will test you on them. Apart from this, I learned and enjoyed this class, which is all I could ask.
If you don't have to take this I would not. It's a lot of stress for no reason. The tests are really difficult and there isn't a lot of provided preparation to help students.

After much waffling between MB&B 300 and this course, I chose this one and it was 100% the right decision. This course is so much easier (there are 4 non-cumulative midterms, no final, section is optional, and no psets) and tends to have fewer hardcore biochem students so the curve is better. I put in around 40 hours total into this class (~10 for each midterm, a little more for the third and a little less for the first) and did fine (granted, I previously took MCDB 200 which has some overlap and knew the amino acid structures from MCAT studying). If Javi is still a TA in the course, make sure to attend his marathon review sessions if you choose to skip class because Breaker occasionally goes randomly in-depth about a topic that is only lightly mentioned in the slides (this is what I did). In previous semesters, Prof. Clay was difficult to understand but she no longer teaches at Yale and Prof. Breaker has taken over her section of the material.
